title: Bowel Management — Empowering Patient Independence
description: Distinguish reflex vs flaccid bowel patterns, educate patients on daily routines and recognise red flags requiring escalation.

screens.title: Reflex vs Flaccid Bowel
screens.body: Reflex bowel follows the gastro‑colic reflex and typically requires daily or second daily evacuation. Flaccid bowel lacks reflex activity and usually requires twice daily manual evacuation and aperient use.

screens.question: Which aperient would you discuss for soft stool maintenance?
screens.explanation: Coloxyl/Senna combines a stool softener with a stimulant, making it suitable for neurogenic bowel regimes.

screens.prompt: Alex reports no bowel motion for three days, increased spasm and headache.

options.result: This treats constipation but does not address potential autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Stop bowel care, check blood pressure and suspect autonomic dysreflexia
options.result: Correct — autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency. Follow the AD protocol and alert your team.
Fluids support bowel health but won’t resolve possible reflex complications.

screens.prompt: Think about your last bowel management teaching session. What made it effective — clear demonstration, empathy or repetition? Jot down your thoughts.
